transcript.text: let's review a debate taking place via
email between none other than noam
chomsky and sam harris
the subject matter will be centered
around collateral damage and the role of
human intentions in the morality of
foreign interventions
the discussion is about 10 000 words
long but can be distilled significantly
harris initiates the debate by citing
some passages of his book the end of
faith where he criticizes chomsky's view
regarding america's foreign
interventions
in his book 911 with rubble of a world
trade center still piled high and
smouldering chomsky urged us not to
forget that the u.s itself is a leading
terrorist state in support of his claim
he catalogues a number of american
misdeeds
including the sanctions that the united
states imposed upon iraq which led to
the death of maybe half a million
children
and the 1998 bombing of the al-shipha
pharmaceutical plant in sudan which may
have set for stage for tens of thousands
of innocent sudanese to die of
tuberculosis malaria and other treatable
diseases
chomsky does not hesitate to draw moral
equivalences here
for the first time in modern history
europe and its offshoots were subjected
on home soil to the kind of atrocity
that they routinely have carried out
elsewhere
for harris there is no moral equivalence
between foreign interventions of western
countries and attacks like 911.
the main argument that he will build and
will be discussed throughout can be
mapped out quite simply his first
premise is delineated by his words on
the intentions of western countries
take the bombing of the al-shifa
pharmaceutical plant
according to chomsky the atrocity of
september 11
pales in comparison with that
perpetrated by the clinton
administration in august 1998
but let us now ask some very basic
questions that chomsky seems to have
neglected to ask himself
what did the us government think it was
doing when it sent cruise missiles into
sudan destroying a chemical weapon site
used by al-qaeda
did the clinton administration intend to
bring about the deaths of thousands of
sudanese children
no was our goal to kill as many sudanese
as we could
no
were we trying to kill anyone at all
not unless we thought members of al
qaeda would be at the al-shafer facility
in the middle of the night
from this harris's second premise can be
intuited
nothing in chomsky's account
acknowledges the difference between
intending to kill a child because of the
effects you hope to produce on its
parents we call this terrorism
and inadvertently killing a child in an
attempt to capture or kill and avowed a
child murderer
we call this collateral damage
in both cases a child has died and in
both cases it's a tragedy but for
ethical status of the perpetrators
either individuals or states could
hardly be more distinct
on these premises harris will rest his
conclusion
for chomsky intentions do not seem to
matter body count is all
chomsky will start off by saying that he
never suggested that there was a moral
equivalence between the al-shifar bomen
and 9 11.
let's turn to what you did say a
disquisition on moral equivalence
you failed to mention though that i did
not suggest that they were morally
equivalent
and in fact indicated quite the opposite
i did not describe the al-shifah bombing
as a horrendous crime committed with
wickedness and awesome cruelty
rather i point out that the toll might
be comparable which on inquiry which is
not undertaken here and which apologists
for a crime ignore turns out to be quite
likely a serious understatement
regarding intentions instead norm
chomsky will levy an attack on sam
harris's first premise
you also ignored the fact that i had
already responded to your claim about
lack of intention the following is from
radical priorities 2003
most commentary on the sudan bombing
keeps to the question of whether the
plant was believed to produce chemical
weapons true or false that has no
bearing on the magnitude of which
regression interfered with key values in
the society attacked such as survival
others point out whether killings were
unintended as are many of atrocities we
rightly denounce
in this case we can hardly doubt that
the likely human consequences were
understood by us planners the acts can
be excused then only on the hegelian
assumption that africans are mere things
whose lives have no value
harris though is still left wondering
what chomsky thinks the significance of
intentions is
it still seems to me that everything you
have written here ignores the moral
significance of intention
the difference between intending to harm
someone and accidentally harming them is
enormous
if for no other reason than that the
presence of harmful intent tells us a
lot about what a personal group is
likely to do in the future
in response chomsky will launch an
offensive on both of harris's premises
if you had read further before launching
your accusations the usual procedure in
work intended to be serious
you would have discovered that i also
reviewed the substantial evidence about
the very sincere intentions of japanese
fascists while they were devastated in
china hitler in the sudetenland and
poland etc
there is at least as much reason to
suppose that they were sincere as
clinton was when he bombed al-shipha
much more so in fact therefore if you
believe what you are saying you should
be justifying their actions as well
i also reviewed other cases pointing out
that professing benign intentions is the
norm for those who carry out atrocities
and crimes perhaps sincerely and surely
more plausibly than in this case
as i've discussed for many years in fact
decades benign intentions are virtually
always professed even by the worst
monsters
and hence carry no information even in
the technical sense of that term
chomsky explains that good intentioned
people can be some of the worst monsters
in history so for him when discussing
from reality or foreign attacks
intentions don't carry any information
but for harris chomsky's position still
appears a bit ambiguous
your ethical position is still unclear
to me you say that you are not claiming
that clinton intentionally wanted to
kill thousands of victims
okay but you seem to be suggesting that
he had every reason to expect that he
would be killing them by his actions and
just didn't care
and you seem disinclined to distinguish
for ethics of these cases
the famous linguist will attempt to
clarify
on moral grounds how do we rank one
intention to kill as compared with two
knowledge that of course you will kill
but you don't care like stepping on ants
when you walk
as for one i have been discussing it for
50 years
explaining in detail why as we all agree
such professed intentions carry little
if any weight
and in fact are quite uninformative
since they are almost entirely
predictable even in the case of the
worst monsters and i have also provided
evidence that they may be quite sincere
even in the case of these monsters but
we of course dismiss them nonetheless
in contrast it seems that you have never
discussed one
as for two i posed the question the one
serious moral question that arises in
the case at issue and though i didn't
give a definite answer i suggested what
i think but one might argue that on
moral grounds two is even more depraved
than one
with this the discussion unceremoniously
ends with no agreement reached
chomsky and harris are great orators and
capable of being very civil and
extremely well spoken
so it was surprising and unfortunate
that the tone of a debate was remarkably
uncharitable and unpleasant chomsky
wasn't jumping for joy to engage with
what harris had written of him
and it showed
the substance was obfuscated by repeated
interjections regarding misreadings of
arguments or unwillingnesses to engage
properly with the questions posed
the title the limits of discourse as
demonstrated by sam harris and norm
chomsky describes quite well what
transpired
regarding the substance of the debate it
was unexpected that harris who espouses
a moral theory that is close to a
version of consequentialism was for one
bringing up the question of intentions
in fact sometimes it is argued that the
flaw of consequentialist moral theories
is that they don't appear to value the
intentions of agents when deciding the
morality of actions
i don't believe these arguments really
work but nonetheless interesting that it
is the quasi-consequentialist to bring
up this point
moving on one of the main counterpoints
chomsky was getting out during the
debate was that one could suppose with
some credibility given historical
precedence that the leaders of terrorist
groups may believe that the civilians
they are killing are collateral damage
to liberate their countries and bring
about sharia law everywhere creating a
paradise on earth or something of the
sort
so we could ultimately have quote
unquote noble intentions as harris
supposes the american government has
i feel like the two debaters could have
found more common ground in
distinguishing the morality of
terrorists and western governments
focusing on which of the respective
approaches was actually more likely to
lead to a better state of affairs for
all
indeed i believe that harris as many
would was implicitly assuming that
america's approach the intended state of
affairs america was trying to bring
about was obviously better
perhaps explicitly distinguishing
between intentions meant as a mental
state in which a person is carrying out
his actions
and the consequences of the intended
state of affairs one is trying to bring
about will produce would have done a
fair bit to clarify the debate and
ultimately shed light on what the moral
difference between the american
government and terrorist groups might be
there would have undoubtedly still been
room for debate but at least the
discussion would have proceeded further
than the limit it reached
